• The system can operate in various modes, including controlling electric lights only, controlling window treatments only, or controlling both electric lights and window treatments, and can also account for manual overrides and adjust for changes in daylight availability throughout the day.</summary>

<summary>
* The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) was established in response to the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, with the primary responsibility of ensuring security in all modes of transportation. TSA has made significant progress in strengthening aviation security, including deploying federal screeners, implementing explosives detection systems, and enhancing air traffic control computer systems and facilities.
* However, vulnerabilities remain in areas such as air cargo, general aviation, and airport perimeter security. TSA has taken steps to address these vulnerabilities, including implementing a known shipper program for air cargo and working with industry stakeholders to improve general aviation security.
* TSA faces several longer-term challenges, including risk management, funding, coordination, strategic human capital management, and building a results-oriented organization. The agency has adopted a risk management approach to guide its efforts and is working to develop a comprehensive plan for air cargo security.
* To sustain aviation security advancements, TSA must continue to build a results-oriented culture, strategically manage its workforce, and ensure effective partnerships with federal, state, and local agencies, as well as the aviation community. The agency must also address concerns about accountability, funding, and the use of technology to improve security while minimizing delays and inconvenience to the public.</summary>

<summary>
• The Lobbying Disclosure Act (LDA) and the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) sections 4911 and 162(e) have different definitions of lobbying, which can affect registration and reporting requirements for organizations that lobby federal officials. The LDA definition covers only federal government officials, while the IRC definitions cover state and local government officials, as well as grassroots lobbying.
• The choice of definition can significantly impact whether an organization must register under LDA and what information they must disclose on their lobbying reports. Organizations using an IRC definition may not have to report expenses related to federal lobbying, and may exclude expenses and information related to lobbying that is not covered under the selected IRC definition.
• Options for revising the statutory framework include harmonizing the definitions, eliminating the authorization for businesses and tax-exempt organizations to use the IRC lobbying definitions for LDA reporting, and requiring organizations that use an IRC definition to include only expenses related to federal lobbying efforts when registering and reporting under LDA. These options aim to improve the alignment of registrations and the comparability of lobbying information reported to Congress.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Government Accountability Office (GAO) has been assessing strategic sourcing in federal acquisitions for over a decade, finding that leading companies have achieved substantial savings through this approach.
• Strategic sourcing involves moving away from individual procurements to a broader aggregate approach, including developing knowledge of spending and taking an enterprise-wide approach to services acquisition.
• The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) implemented strategic sourcing practices in 2005, directing agencies to develop and implement strategic sourcing efforts based on spend analyses.
• The Federal Strategic Sourcing Initiative (FSSI) was established in 2005 to address government-wide opportunities to strategically source commonly purchased products and services.
• Despite these efforts, most agencies have only managed a small fraction of their spending through strategic sourcing, with the Department of Defense, Department of Homeland Security, Department of Energy, and Department of Veterans Affairs accounting for 80% of federal procurement spending but only managing 5% of that spending through strategic sourcing.
• Agencies have reported achieving savings through strategically sourced contracts, but utilization of these contracts is low, with only 15% of government-wide spending for FSSI-covered products and services going through FSSI contracts in fiscal year 2011.
• Impediments to strategic sourcing in the federal setting include challenges in obtaining and analyzing reliable data, securing expertise, leadership support, and developing metrics.
• Leading companies have successfully applied strategic sourcing to services, achieving savings of 4-15% over prior year spending, and have emphasized the importance of analyzing all procurement spending with equal rigor and centralizing procurement decisions.
• Companies have developed category-specific procurement strategies, focusing on total cost of ownership, and tailoring their tactics to fit the complexity of the service and the number of suppliers.
• OMB and other agencies have taken actions to expand the use of strategic sourcing, including issuing guidance on calculating savings and identifying spending categories most suitable for strategic sourcing, but more needs to be done to better incorporate strategic sourcing leading practices and increase the amount of spending through strategic sourcing.
</summary>

<summary>
• The current surface transportation programs in the US are ineffective in addressing the nation's transportation challenges, with unclear federal goals and roles, lack of links to performance, and unsustainable funding. A fundamental reexamination of the federal approach to surface transportation is needed to create more focused, performance-based, and sustainable programs.
• To address the challenges, a framework of principles has been identified, including creating well-defined goals, establishing a clear federal role, incorporating performance and accountability, employing the best tools and approaches, and ensuring fiscal sustainability. Various funding and financing options, such as taxes, user fees, bonding, loans, and public-private partnerships, can be used to support the restructured programs.</summary>

<summary>
• The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) engages in three primary activities: aviation safety oversight, air traffic control (ATC), and airport infrastructure development, with costs depending on the nature and usage of specific services provided.

• The current funding system for FAA relies on a combination of excise taxes, including a ticket tax, passenger segment tax, and fuel taxes, which are deposited into the Airport and Airway Trust Fund (Trust Fund).

• The Trust Fund provides funding for FAA's capital accounts, research and development, and operations, but the current funding system has raised concerns about revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency.

• The disconnect between Trust Fund revenues and FAA costs raises concerns that the current system will not produce adequate revenue to keep pace with FAA's workload increases and costs.

• Alternative funding options, such as a fuel tax, weight/distance charges, en-route charges, flight segment charges, and certification charges, have been proposed to address these concerns.

• Each of these options has advantages and disadvantages, and the degree to which they could address revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency concerns depends on the extent to which the contributions required from users reflect the costs they impose on the system.

• Allowing FAA to use debt financing for capital projects has been proposed as another option, but it raises concerns about encumbering future resources, congressional oversight, and borrowing costs.

• The use of debt financing would require FAA to borrow from the Treasury or private capital market, with the Treasury likely to offer lower interest rates, but the costs of borrowing from the private capital market would depend on the revenue source used to repay the debt.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Department of Defense (DOD) has been working to identify individuals who were potentially exposed to chemical or biological substances during secret tests, including Project 112, but its efforts have been hampered by a lack of clear objectives, inconsistent guidance, and inadequate oversight.
* DOD's current effort to identify individuals who were potentially exposed during tests outside of Project 112 lacks transparency, and the department has not worked with veterans and veterans service organizations as required by the Defense Authorization Act for FY 2003.
* The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) has had limited success in notifying individuals who were potentially exposed, due in part to inconsistent transmission of information from DOD and a lack of effective use of available resources to obtain contact information.
* The Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommends that DOD conduct a cost-benefit analysis to determine the feasibility of continuing to search for additional Project 112 participants, and that VA take steps to increase its use of available resources to notify veterans who were potentially exposed.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Mexican government has been working to combat the growing power of criminal groups, including drug trafficking organizations (DTOs), since 2006, with a shift in emphasis towards reducing criminal violence under President Enrique Peña Nieto.
* Mexican DTOs are involved in various criminal activities, including human trafficking, kidnapping, money laundering, extortion, bribery, racketeering, and weapons trafficking, with a significant portion of their firearms coming from the United States.
* The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) are the primary agencies responsible for combating firearms trafficking, with ATF focusing on domestic firearms violations and ICE handling international trafficking.
* Despite efforts to combat firearms trafficking, challenges persist, including information sharing and coordination between ATF and ICE, as well as corruption among some Mexican officials, which can limit the effectiveness of bilateral efforts.
* The National Southwest Border Counternarcotics Strategy's indicator for tracking progress in stemming firearms trafficking to Mexico is inadequate, as it only measures the number of firearms seized in Mexico and traced by ATF, which does not accurately reflect the volume of firearms trafficked from the United States to Mexico.
* Recommendations have been made to establish a mechanism to regularly monitor the implementation of the memorandum of understanding (MOU) between ATF and ICE, and to develop a more comprehensive indicator or set of indicators to track progress in combating firearms trafficking, which have been agreed upon by the relevant agencies.</summary>

<summary>
• The National Criminal History Improvement Program (NCHIP) is a federal grant program that aims to improve the accuracy, completeness, and accessibility of the nation's criminal history records, with a focus on enhancing the quality of records used by various national systems, including the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS).
• Since its inception in 1995, NCHIP has provided over $438 million in federal grants to states, the District of Columbia, and U.S. territories to help them improve their records and establish automated capabilities that enhance participation in national criminal history records systems.
• States have used NCHIP grant funds primarily to support NICS in conducting background checks of firearms' purchasers, with a majority of funds used for NICS-related purposes, such as converting manual records to automated formats and purchasing equipment to implement computerized systems or upgrade existing systems.
• Despite progress made in automating records, challenges remain, including the availability of automated information on the disposition of felony and other potentially disqualifying arrests, as well as the lack of widely accessible information on domestic violence misdemeanors and noncriminal disqualifying factors.
• The demand for background checks is growing, driven by screening requirements for employment and other noncriminal justice purposes, and technology is not static, necessitating periodic upgrades or replacements of automated systems, highlighting the need for continued funding and support for NCHIP and other programs aimed at improving the nation's criminal history records systems.</summary>

<summary>
* The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) of 1980 created the Superfund program to clean up the nation's most contaminated hazardous waste sites, with the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) responsible for investigating and cleaning up these sites.
* As of December 1996, there were 1,210 sites on the National Priorities List (NPL) for study and cleanup, with EPA selecting incineration as a cleanup remedy in about 6% of cases.
* Incineration involves burning substances in a controlled flame in an enclosed area, with four basic steps: preparing and feeding waste into the incinerator, burning the waste, collecting and cooling ash, and cooling and releasing cleaned gases.
* EPA requires incinerators at Superfund sites to meet Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) standards, including emissions standards, and to have safety features such as automatic waste feed cutoffs.
* EPA uses four principal methods to ensure safe operation of incinerators: setting site-specific standards, incorporating safety features, monitoring emissions, and providing 24-hour on-site oversight.
* Despite these safeguards, EPA has not fully implemented two additional methods to promote safe operation: having RCRA hazardous waste incinerator inspectors evaluate Superfund incinerators and systematically sharing lessons learned from site to site.
* EPA visited three Superfund sites with operating incinerators and found that while the incinerators were operating safely, there were opportunities for improvement, including the need for more formal documentation of lessons learned.
* The report recommends that EPA implement its guidance for having RCRA hazardous waste incinerator inspectors evaluate Superfund incinerators and document and share lessons learned from each site.
* EPA generally agreed with the report's findings and recommendations, but questioned the benefits of preparing voluminous site-specific studies on lessons learned, given the decreasing use of incineration.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Securities and Exchange Commission's (SEC) financial statements for fiscal years 2007 and 2006 were fairly stated in all material respects, but the agency had a material weakness and three significant deficiencies in internal control, which may adversely affect decisions based on inaccurate information and unaudited financial information.
• The material weakness and significant deficiencies identified include control deficiencies in the period-end financial reporting process, disgorgements and penalties accounts receivable, accounting for transaction fee revenue, preparing financial statement disclosures, information security, property and equipment, and accounting for budgetary resources, which require corrective actions to ensure reliable financial reporting and sound operations.</summary>

<summary>
• The US Postal Service had about 765,000 career employees at the end of fiscal year 1997, with 80,238 in Executive and Administrative Schedule (EAS) positions, making up about 10% of the total workforce. The Service's diversity program aimed to provide equal employment opportunities and create a diverse workforce.

• A study by Aguirre International found that while the Service was a leader in meeting affirmative action goals, women and minorities faced problems advancing to management jobs at EAS 17 and above positions. However, the study's finding of a "glass ceiling" was not supported by convincing evidence, and the term's use could be misleading.

• An analysis of workforce data found that women and minorities were underrepresented in EAS 17 and above positions compared to their representation in EAS 11 through 16 positions. However, women and minorities were promoted to EAS 17 and above positions in percentages higher than or close to their workforce representation.

• The Service developed 23 initiatives to improve its diversity program in response to the Aguirre report, including establishing targets and measures to track progress, improving data collection, and increasing diversity in the workforce. However, the Service still lacks reliable data on the flow of applicants through its promotion processes.

• The General Accounting Office (GAO) recommended that the Postmaster General ensure that appropriate Service officials capture EEO group data and use it to identify and remove barriers to the promotion of women and minorities to high-level EAS positions. The Postal Service concurred with the recommendation and planned to reemphasize the need to enter data into the Promotion Report System.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Department of Defense (DOD) defines a Military Working Dog (MWD) as any canine bred, procured, or acquired to meet DOD's requirements for operations, including explosive and narcotic detection, patrol, and tracking. MWDs are removed from service due to medical or behavioral problems, or when they are no longer needed.

• The National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) for FY 2016 established priorities for the adoption of MWDs, giving first priority to former handlers, followed by others capable of humane care, and then law enforcement agencies.

• The Army Veterinary Service is responsible for the medical care of DOD-owned animals, including MWDs, and provides medical care through its Public Health Command Regions and Activities and the DOD MWD Veterinary Service.

• DOD uses three systems to track information on MWDs: the Working Dog Management System (WDMS), the Central Repository, and the ROVR electronic medical record system. These systems document an MWD's status when removed from service, including adoption, transfer, or euthanization.

• Adopted MWDs often have prevalent medical conditions, including skin, dental, and musculoskeletal issues, which can be costly to treat. Nonprofit organizations, such as the U.S. War Dogs Association, offer assistance with veterinary care, including prescription drugs, specialty care, and financial assistance for emergency care and euthanasia.

• Owners of adopted MWDs may also purchase veterinary services through DOD if they have access to medical services at military installations, although the types of services offered vary by installation, and some installations do not offer veterinary services.</summary>

<summary>
* The Comanche program was established in 1983 to replace the Army's light helicopter fleet with a low-cost, lightweight, advanced technology helicopter capable of performing armed reconnaissance and attack missions.
* The program experienced significant increases in program acquisition unit cost, from $12.1 million per aircraft in 1985 to $34.4 million per aircraft in 1995, and funding reductions led to a restructured program with a reduced budget and extended development phase.
* The Army's restructuring of the Comanche program continues to pose risks, including making production decisions before knowing whether the aircraft will perform as required and higher program costs.
* The program's software development is experiencing problems, including delays, configuration management issues, and high turnover of software engineers, which may impact the aircraft's performance and capability.
* The Comanche's maintainability requirements, including direct maintenance man-hours per flight hour, mean time to repair, and fault isolation, are at risk of not being met, which could impact the Army's ability to achieve lower operating and support costs and wartime availability goals.
* The Army has established a requirement of a 1-percent false removal rate for the Comanche, which is considered a high-risk goal, and the program's weight growth is within acceptable limits, but may impact the aircraft's vertical rate of climb performance.
* The General Accounting Office (GAO) recommends that the Secretary of Defense require the Army to complete operational testing to validate the Comanche's operational effectiveness and suitability before committing any funds to acquire long-lead production items or enter low-rate initial production.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Food Stamp Program provides eligible low-income households with benefits that can be redeemed for food in stores nationwide, with the program's rules and regulations established by the Food and Nutrition Service (FNS) and implemented by states. FNS offers various options and waivers to increase program access and reduce the reporting burden on working families, including alternatives to monthly and change reporting, and a transitional benefit option to help families leaving TANF retain their food stamp benefits.
* Almost all states used one or more options or waivers to change their food stamp eligibility determination process, with many states conferring categorical eligibility for food stamps to households receiving certain TANF-funded services or benefits, and exempting some or all vehicles from counting as assets. States also used reporting options and waivers to reduce payment errors, ease program administration, and simplify paperwork requirements for households.
* Despite the availability of options and waivers, some states reported difficulties with the categorical eligibility option, and many states expressed concerns over payment accuracy and the need for additional changes to reporting requirements. The Transitional Benefit Alternative was seen as a way to support working families, but some states were concerned about implementation costs, and no state is implementing or plans to implement all aspects of the Simplified Food Stamp Program option due to its complexity and difficulty in implementation.</summary>

<summary>
* The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) is a federal agency responsible for programs in four areas: housing assistance, community development, housing finance, and regulatory issues. HUD's fiscal year 2000 budget request includes 19 new initiatives and programs, with a total budget of about $28 billion in new discretionary budget authority.
* The proposed budget raises questions about HUD's capacity to manage the increase, as the agency is currently undergoing a significant organizational reform and may not have the necessary resources to plan, implement, and manage the new programs.
* Specific concerns are raised about HUD's Section 8 housing assistance program, including the accuracy of budget proposals and the use of unexpended balances to offset funding needs. Additionally, the Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) Program's set-asides and the Integrated Disbursement and Information System (IDIS) are also areas of concern.
* Other issues include the administration of a new contracting initiative for Section 8 contract administration, the increase in the Urban Empowerment Zones program, and the potential duplication of funding for communities that were not chosen for Round II EZ designation.</summary>

<summary>
* The Military Health System, operated by the Department of Defense (DOD), has a dual health care mission: readiness and benefits, providing medical services and support to the armed forces and their families.
* The DOD's health care mission is carried out through military treatment facilities and civilian health care providers through TRICARE, with the Assistant Secretary of Defense (Health Affairs) responsible for ensuring effective execution.
* The TRICARE Management Activity approved plans to renovate the Landstuhl Regional Medical Center (LRMC) and the 86th Medical Group (MDG) clinic in 2008, but later decided to consolidate the two projects into a single medical center.
* The replacement medical center will serve as the only tertiary-level referral hospital for the European Command, Central Command, and Africa Command theaters of operation, and will be operated and maintained by the Army, with the Air Force providing clinical services.
* The DOD used beneficiary population data and historical patterns of patient migration to determine the size and configuration of the replacement medical center, but the documentation revealed gaps, inconsistencies, and calculation errors.
* The DOD officials incorporated patient quality of care and environmentally friendly design standards into the facility requirements, but the documentation did not clearly explain how the analyses were performed and adjustments were made.
* The cost estimate for the replacement medical center was developed using many best practices, but was minimally documented, and did not include facility sustainment costs, costs for supporting infrastructure, or operation and maintenance costs.
* The GAO found that the DOD's cost estimating methodology substantially met many best practices criteria, but was only minimally documented, and recommended that the Secretary of Defense direct the Assistant Secretary of Defense (Health Affairs) to provide clear documentation on how medical planners applied DOD criteria to determine the facility's requirements.
* The GAO also recommended that the Secretary of Defense direct the Assistant Secretary of Defense (Health Affairs) to revise the cost estimate for the center, incorporating best practices outlined in the GAO Cost Estimating and Assessment Guide, and to update it with revised calculations as part of the recertification process.
* The DOD agreed with the GAO's conclusions and recommendations, and stated that it had conducted a reassessment of the original project, but the reassessment was not available for review at the time of the report.
</summary>

<summary>
• The U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has the authority to apprehend and remove aliens who are in violation of immigration laws, with over 100 violations serving as the basis for removal, including criminal activity, health reasons, and lack of proper documentation.

• ICE officers exercise discretion throughout the alien apprehension and removal process, with the initial phases involving the most discretion, and officers considering factors such as humanitarian concerns and ICE priorities when making decisions.

• The alien apprehension and removal process encompasses six phases: initial encounter, apprehension, charging, detention, removal proceedings, and final removal, with officers having more latitude to exercise discretion in the initial phases.

• ICE has recently expanded its worksite enforcement and fugitive operations, increasing the probability that officers will encounter aliens with humanitarian issues or who are not targets of investigations, highlighting the need for comprehensive guidance to reduce the risk of improper decision making.

• ICE guidance on the exercise of discretion is not comprehensive and has not been updated to reflect expanded worksite and fugitive operations, with officers relying on formal and on-the-job training, guidance from supervisors, and field operational manuals to inform their decision making.

• ICE has taken steps to strengthen training for officers, including implementing worksite enforcement training, supervisory training, and Spanish language training, but the effectiveness of these efforts is yet to be assessed.

• ICE lacks a mechanism to analyze information specific to the exercise of discretion, relying primarily on supervisory reviews and an inspection program that does not offer a mechanism for management to collect and analyze data on officer decision making.

• The Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommends that ICE develop time frames for updating existing policies, develop a mechanism to ensure consistent dissemination of legal updates, and evaluate the costs and alternatives of developing a reporting mechanism to analyze trends in the use of discretion.
</summary>

<summary>
• Ground ambulance services are provided by various organizations with different structures, staffing, and revenue sources, and Medicare payments for these services consist of a service-level payment and a mileage payment.
• Providers may be affiliated with institutions, independent, for-profit, nonprofit, or government-based, and may rely on volunteers, paid staff, or a combination of both, offering nonemergency and emergency transports, as well as basic life support (BLS) and advanced life support (ALS) services.
• Revenue sources for ambulance services include community tax support, charitable donations, state and federal grants, subscription programs, and payments from Medicare, Medicaid, and private health insurance companies.
• Medicare pays ambulance providers through a national fee schedule, with payments having two components: a service-level payment and a mileage payment, and the mileage payment is determined by the number of miles traveled with a patient and the mileage base rate.
• The cost of providing ground ambulance transports varies greatly among providers, ranging from $224 to $2,204 per transport, with a median cost of $429, and the variability in costs is attributed to differences in provider characteristics, such as volume of transports and level of government subsidies.
• The median Medicare margin for ambulance providers was about 2% in 2010, but removing add-on payments resulted in a lower median Medicare margin of -1%, and the increase in ambulance transports from 2004 to 2010 is primarily due to an increase in BLS nonemergency transports.
• The study found that providers with lower transport volumes generally had higher costs per transport, and the use of volunteer staff, receipt of government subsidies, and ownership type were significant factors in explaining the variation in providers' total costs.</summary>

<summary>
• The Department of Defense (DOD) has a department-wide office, Supply Chain Integration, responsible for leading the development of DOD supply chain policies, including those for SRC I ammunition, which is considered a higher risk than other conventional ammunition.

• The Army plays a prominent role in managing SRC I ammunition, as it procures a majority of the department's ammunition and provides wholesale storage for the other military services at Army depots.

• The military services have automated information systems for managing accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition, but the Air Force does not track SRC I ammunition by serial number, and the Army's systems do not provide full accountability for in-transit items.

• The military services generally recorded shipment and receipt of SRC I ammunition in their accountability systems, but the Army and Marine Corps do not have guidance that requires the receipting of SRC I ammunition in a timely manner.

• The Air Force does not maintain accountability for SRC I ammunition items owned by other services but in the physical custody of the Air Force, and instead allows ammunition owned by other services to be tracked in a "non-accountable" program.

• The military services have not consistently ensured timely, complete, and accurate information to maintain full visibility of SRC I ammunition in the continental United States.

• The Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command and the military services have not agreed on the specific information required for the military services to ensure timely data entry into the Defense Transportation Tracking System (DTTS).

• The military services have not always entered timely information in DTTS on SRC I ammunition shipments, and have entered incomplete or inaccurate data in DTTS about shipments of SRC I ammunition.

• The DOD concurred with six recommendations made to enhance the department's policy and procedures and improve the accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition, including revising guidance to clarify that accountability for all SRC I ammunition items in the Air Force's custody should be maintained in the Air Force's system of record.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Social Security Administration (SSA) is the largest single producer, collector, and user of information in the United States, with virtually billions of records, including personal information such as name, date of birth, address, and Social Security numbers (SSNs).

• The SSA's disclosure policy is designed to protect the privacy rights of individuals to the fullest extent possible while permitting the exchange of records required to fulfill its administrative and program responsibilities.

• The Privacy Act of 1974 is the primary law governing the protection of personal privacy by agencies of the federal government, and it regulates the collection, maintenance, use, and disclosure of personal information that federal agencies maintain in a system of records.

• The SSA's disclosure policy is more restrictive than the Privacy Act and the disclosure policies of most federal agencies, with the IRS and Census Bureau being exceptions, as their policies are specifically provided in statute.

• The SSA's policy allows the disclosure of information to law enforcement under certain conditions, such as when the criminal activity involves fraud or other crimes in Social Security programs, nonviolent crimes and criminal activity in other government programs, and violent and serious crimes.

• The SSA's Office of the Inspector General (OIG) is authorized to disclose individuals' personal information to law enforcement agencies under a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the SSA.

• The SSA's disclosure policy is not always consistently applied, with some field office staff and local law enforcement officers finding the policy confusing and sometimes frustrating.

• The SSA has taken steps to ensure the consistent application of its disclosure policy, including providing training to staff, posting the policy on its internal website, and making a regional "privacy coordinator" available to answer staff questions.

• The General Accounting Office (GAO) recommends that the Commissioner of SSA take steps to eliminate confusion about the agency's disclosure policy and provide law enforcement with information on SSA's disclosure policy and procedures.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) of 1976, amended in 1984, regulates the management of hazardous waste from generation to disposal, aiming to minimize threats to human health and the environment.
* RCRA's requirements can create disincentives for industry to clean up previously contaminated sites, particularly those managed under state voluntary programs, due to increased costs and time.
* Three RCRA requirements - land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and permit requirements - are often cited as the most significant barriers to cleanups, leading parties to choose less aggressive remedies or avoid cleanups altogether.
* Land disposal restrictions can be costly and complex, requiring treatment to specific standards that may be more stringent than necessary for lightly contaminated media, and can drive parties to use more costly technologies.
* Minimum technological requirements can be counterproductive for some cleanups, adding unnecessary costs, and may not be suitable for remediation waste from temporary or low-risk sources.
* Permit requirements can cause significant delays and costs, with the process of obtaining a permit involving substantial documentation and review, and can discourage parties from conducting cleanups.
* EPA has developed policy and regulatory alternatives to mitigate the impact of RCRA's requirements, including the "contained-in" policy, permit waivers, site-specific variances, and the corrective action management unit (CAMU) rule.
* However, these alternatives have been inconsistently applied, and stakeholders have raised concerns about their effectiveness, leading EPA to conclude that comprehensive reform of RCRA's requirements for remediation waste can best be achieved through legislation.
* EPA has proposed new rules to reform RCRA's requirements, but disagreements among stakeholders have delayed the process, and the agency has announced plans to withdraw its proposed rule and focus on more narrow regulatory changes.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Medicare Integrity Program (MIP) was established in 1996 to support Medicare program integrity activities, with dedicated funding provided by the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA). MIP funds are used to conduct five program integrity activities: audits, medical review, secondary payer, benefit integrity, and provider education.

• The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) allocates MIP funds primarily based on historical funding, with limited consideration of quantitative data or qualitative information on the relative effectiveness of its program integrity activities or contractors' vulnerabilities. This approach may not ensure that funds are being spent as effectively as possible.

• CMS is developing new measures to evaluate the relative effectiveness of provider education and audit activities, which may help the agency make more informed funding allocation decisions. However, the agency's current allocation approach will not be adequate to address emerging program integrity risks and ongoing programmatic changes, such as the addition of the new Part D prescription drug benefit and Medicare contracting reform.

• The Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommends that CMS develop a method of allocating MIP funds based on the effectiveness of its program integrity activities, contractors' workloads, and risk. CMS generally agrees with this recommendation, but notes that some MIP activities have benefits that cannot be easily quantified and that historical funding and other factors should also be considered in allocating MIP funds.</summary>

<summary>
* The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has taken steps to enhance training for screeners and supervisors, including the development of a basic screener training program, recurrent training modules, and leadership training for supervisors. However, challenges remain in providing access to recurrent training, including insufficient staffing and lack of high-speed internet connectivity at some training facilities.
* TSA has implemented various measures to assess and enhance screener performance, including covert testing, the Threat Image Projection (TIP) system, and annual recertification testing. However, these efforts have primarily focused on passenger screening, and TSA has not yet established performance targets for the individual components of its performance indexes.
* TSA has not established clear policies and procedures for documenting completion of required remedial training, and the agency's current guidance for Federal Security Directors (FSDs) does not clearly identify responsibility for tracking and ensuring compliance with training requirements. This lack of clarity may compromise TSA's ability to provide reasonable assurance that screeners are receiving mandated basic and remedial training.
* To address these challenges, the report recommends that TSA develop a plan to prioritize and schedule the deployment of high-speed internet connectivity to all airport training facilities and establish internal controls to clearly define responsibilities for monitoring and documenting the completion of required training. Additionally, TSA should develop performance targets for the individual components of its performance indexes to enable more meaningful analysis of screener performance.</summary>

<summary>
* The IRS faces challenges in managing its human capital to provide telephone customer service to taxpayers, including the lack of a long-term, desired service-level goal, difficulties in recruiting, training, and retaining customer service representatives, and inefficient scheduling and use of staff.
* The IRS has made or planned substantial improvements to help meet these challenges, including establishing a long-term level-of-service goal, developing a system for assessing customer service representatives' competency gaps, and improving workload planning to ensure that customer needs are considered during the planning and budgeting process.
* To improve its human capital management practices, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue should establish a long-term, desired service-level goal, develop a system for assessing customer service representatives' competency gaps, monitor call center attrition, and ensure that evaluations of human capital management practices consider the effects of those practices on the ability to achieve long- and short-term customer service goals.</summary>

<summary>
* Ginnie Mae is a government-owned corporation that provides guarantees for mortgage-backed securities (MBS) issued by private companies, with the goal of expanding affordable housing in America. The agency operates as a unit of the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) and its administrative, staffing, and budgetary decisions are coordinated with HUD's. Ginnie Mae's market share of the total MBS market has declined significantly since 1985, but it continues to finance the bulk of government-backed loans.
* Ginnie Mae's outstanding volume of MBS has declined in recent years due to the decline in the outstanding volume of FHA and VA loans, as growing numbers of borrowers refinance in the conventional market. The agency's share of the government-backed mortgage market has been fairly constant, but its share of the total MBS market has declined substantially over the past 20 years. Despite this, Ginnie Mae continues to serve its key public policy goal of providing a strong secondary market outlet for federally insured and guaranteed housing programs.
* Ginnie Mae faces challenges in a number of areas, including responding to changes in the marketplace, adequately disclosing loan information to MBS investors, working within the limits of its commitment authority, and ensuring the integrity of its data systems. The agency has taken steps to address these challenges, including expanding its product offerings, improving its disclosures, and implementing new policies and procedures.
* Ginnie Mae's future success will depend on its ability to adapt to changes in the marketplace and to continue to provide a strong secondary market outlet for federally insured and guaranteed housing programs. The agency will need to balance its goal of expanding affordable housing with the need to manage its risk and ensure the integrity of its data systems. Closer consultation with lawmakers and capital market participants could help ensure that congressionally mandated provisions of loan programs are consistent with Ginnie Mae and conventional secondary market requirements.</summary>

<summary>
* The Department of Defense (DOD) has made progress in addressing the issues of illegal and otherwise improper closed account adjustments, with a significant reduction of 80% in such adjustments during the first 6 months of fiscal year 2002.
* DOD has reversed $592 million (96%) of the $615 million of illegal and otherwise improper adjustments identified in a prior report, but the reversal of these transactions has brought to light additional accounting problems that require detailed reviews to correct.
* The remaining $23 million of adjustments that have not been reversed include $8 million that DOD has deemed proper and $15 million that are still considered unnecessary or unsupported.
* DOD's contract reconciliation system (CRS) and other controls have been upgraded to prevent illegal and otherwise improper adjustments, but the system still has limitations, and DOD estimates that it will take over 21,000 hours to correct the accounting for 30 contracts.
* The use of numerous appropriation control records (ACRNs) and changes in contract payment allocation terms have contributed to the complexity of contract accounting and the need for adjustments, with some contracts having over 1,000 ACRNs and requiring extensive rework to correct errors.
* The General Accounting Office (GAO) recommends that DOD continue to monitor and correct closed account adjustments, and that the Congress consider options to eliminate or reduce such adjustments, including prohibiting adjustments to closed accounts or allowing a limited period for corrections after an account is closed.</summary>

<summary>
• The Internet's domain name system, which translates domain names into numerical addresses, is critical to the stability and security of the Internet, and its management is being transitioned from the US government to a private sector organization, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN).
• ICANN has made progress in increasing competition in the domain name registration market, but has been slow to address other guiding principles outlined in the Department of Commerce's White Paper, including improving the security and stability of the Internet, ensuring representation of the Internet community, and using private, bottom-up coordination.
• The transition process is at a critical juncture, with ICANN's president calling for fundamental reform and the Department of Commerce facing a decision on whether to extend the current Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with ICANN, amend it, or establish a new arrangement, and it is recommended that the Secretary of Commerce issue a status report on the progress of the transition and the prospects for a successful outcome.</summary>

<summary>
* The Office of the Special Trustee for American Indians (OST) was established in 1994 to reform the management of Indian trust funds, and it has made significant progress in implementing trust fund management reforms, with most key reforms expected to be completed by November 2007.
* However, OST has not developed a timetable for completing the remaining trust reform activities or identified a date for its termination, as required by the 1994 Act, which has hindered congressional oversight and planning for trust fund operations.
* OST has not developed a plan for future trust fund operations once reforms are completed, and it is unclear where OST responsibilities will be transferred if the office is terminated.
* OST has relied heavily on contractors to implement trust reforms, with nearly 21% of its appropriated funds spent on contracts in fiscal years 2004 and 2005, and it plans to reduce funding for contracting as reforms are completed.
* The Special Trustee believes that OST's staff will need to continue to perform their functions after trust reforms are completed, but a reexamination of OST's workforce needs may identify opportunities for realigning or further reducing expenditures and staffing levels.
* The General Accounting Office (GAO) recommends that the Secretary of the Interior direct the Special Trustee to provide a timetable for completing trust fund management reforms, a plan for future trust fund operations, and a workforce plan that reexamines staffing levels and funding needs.
* Interior agreed with the GAO's recommendations and expects to have a timetable for implementing the remaining trust reforms by late June 2007, but disagreed with the number of key reforms identified by the GAO.
</summary>

<summary>
* In 1998, the VA and DOD began a joint effort to develop a comprehensive, life-long medical record for each service member, starting with the Government Computer-Based Patient Record (GCPR) project, which aimed to create an electronic interface for sharing patient health information.
* The GCPR project was later refocused and renamed the Federal Health Information Exchange (FHIE) program, which enabled the one-way transfer of data from DOD's health information system to a separate database accessible to VA clinicians.
* The FHIE program was fully operational by December 2004, with VA providers having access to data on separated service members, and the repository containing historical clinical health data on 2.3 million unique patients.
* The departments are working towards a longer-term goal of achieving a two-way exchange of health information between DOD and VA, known as HealthePeople (Federal), which involves developing a common health information architecture and standardized data.
* Two demonstration projects, Bidirectional Health Information Exchange (BHIE) and Laboratory Data Sharing Interface (LDSI), have been implemented to exchange electronic medical information between existing systems, with BHIE enabling near-real-time access to patient medical information and LDSI allowing for the sharing of laboratory resources.
* The departments are also working on the CHDR initiative, which aims to develop an electronic interface between the data repositories for their new health information systems, with a prototype demonstrating the two-way exchange of pharmacy information and a revised project management plan being developed.
* Despite progress, the departments face challenges in achieving their long-term goals, including the need for a more detailed project management plan, the complexity of implementing standards for pharmacy and medication allergy data, and limitations in the health information currently in the data repositories.</summary>

<summary>
* The Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) describes the desired outcome of an income tax audit as determining the correct taxable income and tax liability of the person or entity under audit, with the auditor responsible for conducting a quality audit.
* IRS uses nine audit standards to define audit quality, including standards for scope, techniques, technical conclusions, reports, and time management, with each standard having one or more key elements.
* Audit workpapers are a crucial part of the audit effort, providing documentation on the scope of the audit, procedures applied, tests performed, and evidence gathered, and serving as the principal support for the auditor's report.
* However, a review of IRS audit workpapers found that auditors did not always meet the requirements laid out under the workpaper standard, with problems including tax adjustments not agreeing, required documents or summaries missing, and workpapers not being legible or complete.
* Supervisory review during audits is a primary tool in IRS' efforts to control quality, but a review of sampled audits found little documentation of supervisory review, with only about 6% of workpapers containing documentation of group manager review during the audit.
* The report recommends that the IRS Commissioner require audit supervisors to document their review of audit workpapers as a control over the quality of audits and associated workpapers, with IRS agreeing to make revisions to the IRM instructions to implement this recommendation by October 1998.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Antiterrorism Assistance (ATA) program, authorized by Congress in 1983, aims to enhance the antiterrorism skills of friendly countries through training and equipment. However, the program lacks adequate strategic planning, performance measurement, and sustainability assessment, which may limit its effectiveness in supporting broader U.S. counterterrorism policy goals.
* The program's management and implementation are hindered by minimal guidance from the Coordinator for Counterterrorism (S/CT), weaknesses in needs assessments and program reviews, and a lack of clear measures and processes for assessing sustainability. Additionally, the program's annual reports contain inaccurate data and lack systematic assessments of program results.
* To improve the ATA program, the Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommends that the Secretary of State revisit and revise internal guidance, ensure that needs assessments and program reviews are useful and linked to resource decisions, establish clearer measures of sustainability, and comply with the congressional mandate to report on U.S. international counterterrorism assistance.</summary>

<summary>
• There are two approaches for reorganizing or terminating a large financial company: judicial bankruptcy process and special legal and regulatory resolution regimes for insolvent financial entities.

• The U.S. bankruptcy system involves multiple federal entities, including bankruptcy courts, the Judicial Conference of the United States, the Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts (AOUSC), the Federal Judicial Center, the Department of Justice's U.S. Trustee Program, and the judiciary's Bankruptcy Administrator Program.

• Large, complex financial companies that are eligible to file for bankruptcy generally file under Chapter 11 of the Code, which allows debtors to continue some or all of their operations subject to court supervision.

• The resolution of globally active large financial firms is often associated with complex international, legal, and operational challenges, including conflicting regulatory regimes and the treatment of cross-border derivatives.

• Chapter 15 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, based on the Model Law on Cross-Border Insolvency of the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law (UNCITRAL), promotes coordination between courts in different countries during insolvencies.

• The Financial Stability Board (FSB) and the European Union (EU) have taken actions to facilitate cross-border resolutions, including the development of principles to guide the development of resolution regimes for financial firms active in multiple countries.

• The U.S. has not made statutory changes to Chapter 15 of the Code or the U.S. judicial bankruptcy process to address impediments to an orderly resolution of a large, multinational financial institution.

• The Federal Reserve and FDIC have taken regulatory actions to facilitate orderly resolution, including requiring large financial companies to provide periodic reports of their plans for rapid and orderly resolution in the event of material financial distress or failure.

• The International Swaps and Derivatives Association (ISDA) has developed a Resolution Stay Protocol to facilitate the cross-border resolution of a large, complex institution, which includes limitations on termination rights and other remedies in the event of certain resolution proceedings.

• The bankruptcy cases of Lehman Brothers Holdings, Inc., MF Global Holdings, Ltd., and Washington Mutual, Inc. have made progress, with distributions to creditors and ongoing litigation, but no new bankruptcy filings of large financial companies have been reported.
</summary>

<summary>
* The electricity industry is composed of four distinct functions: generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations, which are increasingly reliant on computerized technologies and susceptible to cyber-based threats.
* The industry's modernization, including the integration of smart grid systems, aims to increase reliability, efficiency, and the use of alternative energy sources, but also introduces new cybersecurity risks.
* The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) regulates wholesale electricity sales and transmission, while state public utility commissions oversee local distribution and retail sales.
* The North American Electric Reliability Corporation (NERC) is responsible for ensuring the reliability of the bulk power system and has developed critical infrastructure protection standards for cybersecurity.
* The Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 established federal policy to support the modernization of the electricity grid and required actions by federal agencies, including the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) and FERC.
* NIST has identified cybersecurity standards for smart grid systems and developed a framework for improving the cybersecurity and resilience of critical infrastructure.
* FERC has reviewed and approved NERC's critical infrastructure protection standards, but has not adopted NIST's smart grid standards due to insufficient consensus.
* Multiple entities, including NERC, NIST, FERC, and the Departments of Homeland Security and Energy, have taken steps to help secure the electricity grid, but challenges remain, including monitoring implementation of cybersecurity standards, clarifying regulatory responsibilities, and taking a comprehensive approach to cybersecurity.
* The electric industry lacks effective mechanisms for sharing cybersecurity information and establishing metrics for evaluating cybersecurity, making it difficult to determine the effectiveness of investments in cybersecurity.
* Continued attention and action are needed to mitigate the risks posed by cyber threats to the electricity grid, including monitoring the implementation of voluntary cybersecurity standards and addressing the challenges identified in previous reports.
</summary>

<summary>
• The federal workforce faces significant skills gaps, particularly in mission-critical areas such as cybersecurity and acquisitions, which can impede the government's ability to serve the public effectively.

• The federal government's pay system is outdated, rewarding length of service rather than individual performance and contributions, and providing automatic across-the-board pay increases.

• The General Schedule (GS) classification system has not kept pace with the evolving requirements of the federal government, and its guiding principle of equal pay for substantially equal work is not always met.

• The federal workforce is becoming more highly educated and skilled, with a greater need for professional, administrative, and technical roles, but the pay system does not reflect this shift.

• Congress has provided agencies with exemptions from the current pay system to give them more flexibility in setting pay, but a more comprehensive update to the federal compensation system is needed.

• A market-based and performance-oriented pay system is desirable, but it requires effective performance management systems, a cultural shift, and safeguards to ensure fairness and transparency.

• The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) has taken steps to address these issues, including revising its strategic human capital management regulation and providing guidance on performance management.

• However, more needs to be done to address poor performance, improve the capacity of human resource offices, and provide training on leadership and management skills.

• The federal government's hiring process is also in need of improvement, with a need for a more applicant-friendly and flexible process that is consistent with statutory requirements.

• Ultimately, agencies must identify options to meet their missions with fewer resources, and the federal compensation system must be updated to allow the government to cost-effectively attract, motivate, and retain a high-performing workforce.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Department of Defense (DOD) received about $52.4 billion and $62.1 billion in supplemental appropriations for the Global War on Terrorism (GWOT) in fiscal years 2004 and 2005, respectively, to cover military personnel and operation and maintenance expenses.

• The DOD also received additional funds through its annual appropriations, with the Army, Air Force, and Navy receiving about $7.9 billion and $7.6 billion in fiscal years 2004 and 2005, respectively, which were intended to support GWOT.

• However, the DOD lost visibility over these funds and does not know the extent to which they are being used to support GWOT, as the accounting systems do not separately identify these additional appropriations and there are no reporting requirements.

• In fiscal year 2004, the military services reported obligations in support of GWOT that were above the supplemental funds appropriated by the Congress, and DOD used authorities granted to it, including transferring funds and reducing or deferring planned spending for peacetime operations, to cover the gaps.

• If the additional funds included in DOD's annual appropriation to help fund the war are included in the analysis, those funds could potentially have reduced the Army's gap and eliminated the gap for the Air Force and Navy in fiscal year 2004.

• In fiscal year 2005, the Army and the Air Force are again projecting obligations for the war above their supplemental appropriations, and DOD is taking steps to cover the gaps, including exercising authorities provided to them, such as transferring and reprogramming funds from annual appropriations and reducing or deferring planned spending for peacetime operations.

• The DOD is not explicitly considering the Program Budget Decision 736 funds to support GWOT that were provided to the military services through their annual appropriations, and instead, the Office of the Under Secretary of Defense (Comptroller) and the military services will meet those needs by taking actions that may affect DOD's peacetime operations.

• The General Accounting Office (GAO) recommends that the Secretary of Defense adjust future supplemental appropriations requests to reflect the additional funds DOD received in its annual appropriations to support GWOT and provide the Congress with an explanation of these adjustments.

• The GAO also recommends that the Congress direct DOD, when it submits future supplemental appropriations requests, to provide an explanation of how such requests reflect the additional funds that were addressed in Program Budget Decision 736 and which DOD requested and received in its annual appropriations to support GWOT

<summary>
• The Department of the Treasury (Treasury) extended the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) through October 3, 2010, to address ongoing weaknesses in the economy, particularly in the housing market and small business lending, and to maintain the capacity to respond to unforeseen threats or unanticipated shocks. The extension allowed Treasury to reallocate existing commitments and make additional funds available for some programs, such as the Making Home Affordable Program (MHA) and small business lending programs through the Consumer & Business Lending Initiative (CBLI).
• Treasury's decision to extend TARP was informed by a range of quantitative indicators, including housing market indicators, small business lending data, and financial market prices and quantities. However, Treasury's analytical framework for decision-making could be strengthened by identifying clear objectives for small business programs and explaining how relevant indicators motivated TARP program decisions, as well as by developing a more robust framework for evaluating the effectiveness of its programs and making decisions about the timing of exits.</summary>

<summary>
* The FDA and USDA are responsible for ensuring the safety of food products in the United States, with the FDA overseeing all foods except meat, poultry, and certain egg products, which are under the USDA's jurisdiction.
* The agencies use a regulatory system of preventive controls, known as the Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point (HACCP) system, to minimize the risk of contamination, but this system does not specifically address intentional contamination.
* In response to concerns about deliberate contamination, FDA and USDA issued voluntary security guidelines to the food-processing industry, but the agencies do not have the authority to mandate security measures and are concerned that collecting information on industry's security efforts could be subject to Freedom of Information Act requests.
* The agencies have taken steps to enhance security, including increasing inspections and providing training, but they lack comprehensive information on the extent to which food processors are implementing security measures, and the industry is concerned about sharing sensitive information with federal agencies.
* The report recommends that the Secretaries of Health and Human Services and Agriculture study their agencies' existing statutes and identify what additional authorities they may need relating to security measures at food-processing facilities, and provide training for their agencies' field staff on the security measures discussed in the voluntary guidelines.
</summary>

<summary>
* The largest interagency contracting vehicle is the Multiple Award Schedule (MAS) program, also known as the Federal Supply Schedule or the Schedules Program, which is directed and managed by the General Services Administration (GSA).
* Government buyers usually pay a fee for using other agencies' Governmentwide Acquisition Contracts (GWACs), Multiple Award Contracts (MACs), and schedule contracts, which are typically a percentage of the procurement value.
* In fiscal year 2008, federal agencies spent at least $60 billion through GWACs, MACs, the MAS program, and enterprisewide contracts to buy goods and services.
* The MAS program is the primary governmentwide buying program aimed at helping the federal government leverage its significant buying power when buying commercial goods and services.
* Despite the advantages of interagency and enterprisewide contracts, the federal government lacks reliable and comprehensive data to effectively leverage, manage, and oversee these contracts.
* The total number of MACs and enterprisewide contracts currently approved and in use by agencies is unknown due to insufficient and unreliable data in the Federal Procurement Data System-Next Generation (FPDS-NG).
* Concerns remain about contract duplication, with vendors and agency officials expressing concerns about duplication of effort among these contracts, resulting in increased costs and missed opportunities to leverage the government's buying power.
* GSA faces challenges in effectively managing the MAS program, including a lack of transactional data, limited use of pricing tools, and a decentralized management structure.
* To address these challenges, recommendations have been made to improve data, strengthen policy, and better coordinate agencies' awards of MACs and enterprisewide contracts, as well as to improve MAS program management and pricing.
</summary>

<summary>
* The U.S. government has established two programs, 18F and USDS, to improve the management of IT acquisitions and operations, with a focus on providing digital services to citizens. Both programs have provided useful services to federal agencies, with most surveyed agency project managers expressing satisfaction with the services provided.
* However, both 18F and USDS have room for improvement in establishing outcome-oriented goals, measuring performance, and prioritizing projects. For example, 18F's goals and performance measures are not always outcome-oriented, and the program has not fully measured its performance. USDS has also not established performance measures and targets for all of its goals.
* The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) has a key role in helping federal agencies manage their IT investments, and has established policies and guidance for agency CIOs. However, USDS policy does not require agencies to define the expected responsibilities and authorities governing the relationships between CIOs and digital service teams, which is inconsistent with federal law and OMB guidance.
* To address these issues, the Government Accountability Office (GAO) has made recommendations to the General Services Administration (GSA) and OMB, including ensuring that goals and performance measures are outcome-oriented, assessing actual results, and establishing a time frame for developing a report on high-priority projects. The GAO has also recommended that OMB update USDS policy to clearly define the responsibilities and authorities governing the relationships between CIOs and digital service teams.</summary>

<summary>
* The aging of the baby boom generation will lead to significant changes in the ratio of working-age population to those aged 65 or older, with the aged dependency ratio expected to rise from 21% in 2000 to 35% by 2030.
* The number of older workers (55 and over) will grow substantially over the next two decades, with 31.8 million older labor force participants projected by 2015, and 33.3 million by 2025, driven by the aging of the baby boom generation and increased labor force participation among older persons.
* Older workers are employed in a diverse range of occupations, but are increasingly concentrated in white-collar occupations, with 62% of workers aged 55-64 and 65-74 employed in these occupations, and are projected to make relatively greater gains in earnings than their younger counterparts between 2000 and 2008.
* Flexible employment arrangements, such as part-time work, seasonal or part-year work, and consulting or contracting, can help extend the work lives of older workers, but are not yet widespread in the private sector, with only 16% of employers offering such arrangements, and 2% offering them specifically to older workers.
* To address the challenges posed by an aging workforce, the report recommends that the Secretary of Labor convene an interagency task force to develop legislative and regulatory proposals to extend the work life of older Americans, including changes to pension laws and regulations, and to encourage employers to offer flexible employment arrangements and other incentives to retain older workers.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Visa Waiver Program (VWP) was created in 1986 to facilitate legitimate travel of visitors for business or tourism, and it was made permanent in 2000. The program allows visa-free travel to the United States for citizens of participating countries.

• To qualify for the VWP, a country must offer reciprocal visa-free travel privileges to U.S. citizens, have a low refusal rate for visa applications, issue machine-readable passports, and enter into agreements with the United States to share information on lost and stolen passports and potential security threats.

• The program has expanded to 36 countries, and participating countries must meet certain requirements, including having a refusal rate of less than 3% for visa applications and issuing e-passports with biometric identifiers.

• The Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) was implemented in 2008 to enhance program security and requires VWP travelers to apply for approval prior to travel to the United States.

• ESTA has reduced the burden on VWP travelers in several ways, including reducing the need to provide biographical information and allowing for earlier notice of ineligibility. However, the program has also imposed a new fee and pre-travel requirement.

• Despite efforts to minimize the burden, almost all government and travel industry officials expressed dissatisfaction with the ESTA fee, which is used to fund ESTA operations and promote travel to the United States.

• The 9/11 Act requires VWP countries to enter into information-sharing agreements with the United States, but only half of the countries have entered into all required agreements, and many agreements have not been implemented.

• The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has not completed half of the mandated biennial reports on VWP countries in a timely manner, which is required to assess the security, law enforcement, and immigration interests of the United States.

• To address these issues, the Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommends that the Secretary of Homeland Security establish time frames for reviewing cases of VWP passengers traveling without verified ESTA approval and take steps to address delays in the biennial country review process.
</summary>

<summary>
• State child welfare systems face challenges in keeping pace with the needs of troubled children and their families due to growing caseloads, with the foster care population increasing from 276,000 in 1984 to 494,000 in 1995.

• The federal government plays a crucial role in financing foster care and establishing minimum procedural requirements for the placement process, including the requirement for states to make reasonable efforts to prevent or eliminate the need for removing children from their homes.

• The Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 requires states to develop a case plan for each child, review it every 6 months, and hold a permanency hearing within 18 months to determine the child's future status.

• Twenty-six states have enacted laws or policies to shorten the time between entering foster care and the first permanency hearing, with 23 states enacting laws and three states implementing policies through administrative action.

• Some states have implemented innovative approaches to expedite the permanency process, such as concurrent planning, which involves working towards reuniting a family while developing an alternate plan for permanently removing the child if reunification efforts fail.

• States have also implemented low-cost, creative methods for financing and providing services that address specific barriers to reuniting families, such as Arizona's Housing Assistance Program, which helped reunite 939 children with their families between 1991 and 1995.

• Despite these efforts, the lack of systematic evaluations and outcome data makes it difficult to assess the effectiveness of these initiatives, and unintended consequences, such as increasing the number of children in long-term foster care, may arise.

• Successful initiatives require long-term involvement of officials in leadership positions, involvement of key stakeholders, and the availability of resources to plan, implement, and sustain the project, as well as evaluations designed to assess the impact of the effort.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Digital Accountability and Transparency Act (DATA Act) was signed into law on May 9, 2014, to improve federal spending transparency by requiring the disclosure of federal agency expenditures and linking agency spending information to federal program activities.

• The DATA Act requires government-wide reporting on a greater variety of federal funds, including budget and financial information, and tracking of these funds at multiple points in the federal spending lifecycle.

• The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and the Department of the Treasury are responsible for leading government-wide implementation of the DATA Act, with OMB releasing policy guidance and Treasury developing technical guidance for agency submissions and publication of data.

• OMB has taken steps to help agencies meet their reporting requirements, including establishing standardized data element definitions, issuing guidance to operationalize selected standards, and meeting with agencies to assess their readiness.

• However, agencies have identified challenges in reporting certain intragovernmental transactions, missing or incorrect ZIP+4 information, and linking financial and award data using unique award identifiers.

• The DATA Act broker is expected to extract award and sub-award information from four award systems, but these systems have previously been found to contain inaccurate or incomplete data.

• The Government Accountability Office (GAO) has identified risks to data quality related to known material weaknesses and other deficiencies, including internal controls over financial reporting, financial management systems, and information technology security and controls.

• The GAO has made several recommendations to improve the completeness and accuracy of data submissions, including clarifying guidance on agency responsibilities, developing a government-wide oversight process, and establishing a data governance structure.

• The OMB and Treasury have taken some steps to address these recommendations, but more work is needed to ensure effective implementation of the DATA Act and improve the quality of federal spending data.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Office of Special Counsel (OSC) has an agreement with the Acquisition and Contracting Services (ARC) to provide contracting support for a fee, as OSC does not have in-house contracting staff.
* The agreement between ARC and OSC is a mechanism for interagency contracting, which involves three parties: the agency requiring a good or service, the agency placing the order or awarding the contract, and the contractors that provide the goods and services.
* In contracting with MPRI for an organizational assessment, OSC did not follow proper procedures, including not seeking competition among Schedule vendors and not adequately justifying a sole-source order.
* The sole-source justification listed by OSC was not sufficient, and ARC contracting officials did not question or validate the justification, relying instead on OSC's input.
* OSC officials performed duties normally done by contracting officer's representatives without authorization or training, and ARC contracting staff were not aware of this until informed by the investigators.
* The tasks specified in the statement of work for a consultant hired by OSC were consistent with OPM criteria for appropriate uses of expert and consultant appointments.
* OSC employees who believe a prohibited personnel practice has occurred may seek redress through the agency's administrative grievance system or by filing a complaint with OSC, but there are limitations and potential conflicts of interest when allegations are made against the Special Counsel or Deputy Special Counsel.
* To address these limitations, options could include establishing a right to an external investigation through an independent entity or expanding the personnel actions that could be the basis for an appeal directly to the MSPB.
* The report recommends that ARC and OSC take steps to ensure that proper contracting procedures are followed, including careful review of documents and ensuring that only authorized officials act as contracting officer's representatives.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) is the second-largest federal department, with a mission to promote the health, welfare, and dignity of all veterans by providing medical care, benefits, social support, and lasting memorials.
* The VA has three major components: the Veterans Benefits Administration (VBA), the Veterans Health Administration (VHA), and the National Cemetery Administration (NCA), which rely on approximately 340,000 employees to provide services and benefits.
* The VA operates and maintains an IT infrastructure to support its medical centers, veteran-facing systems, benefits delivery systems, memorial services, and other IT systems, including 240 information systems, 314,000 desktop computers, and 30,000 laptops.
* However, many of the VA's systems are old, with two systems identified as being over 50 years old, including the Personnel and Accounting Integrated Data (PAID) system and the Benefits Delivery Network (BDN) system.
* The VA has plans to modernize or replace these legacy systems, including replacing PAID with the Human Resources Information System Shared Service Center and rolling the capabilities of BDN into another system.
* The VA has also initiated an effort to transform its Office of Information and Technology (OI&T) to focus on stabilizing and streamlining processes, mitigating weaknesses, and improving outcomes.
